get.summary: Read configuration of WLAN SSID profile
get.description:
A WLAN SSID (Service Set Identifier) is a unique identifier that names a wireless local area network (WLAN). It is essentially
the network name that is broadcast by a wireless access point (AP) to allow devices to identify and connect to the network. The SSID name can be up to 32
characters long and is case-sensitive. The SSID numbers can be up to 16 for per device. This feature is only applicable for AP.

post.summary: Create a new WLAN SSID profile by unique name

get.summary: Read existing WLAN SSID profile configuration

patch.summary: Update existing WLAN SSID profile configuration

delete_object_type.name: object_type
delete_object_type.description: LOCAL - To delete local objects. SHARED - To delete shared objects. Default - Defaults to SHARED if not provided

delete_scope_id.name: scope_id
delete_scope_id.description: Scope at which local object needs to be deleted. Mandatory if object_type = LOCAL. Should not be provided for object_type = SHARED.

delete_persona.name: persona
delete_persona.description: Persona for which the local object needs to be deleted. Mandatory if object_type = LOCAL. Should not be provided for object_type = SHARED.

post_object_type.name: object_type
post_object_type.description: LOCAL - To create local objects. SHARED - To create shared objects. Default - Defaults to SHARED if not provided

post_scope_id.name: scope_id
post_scope_id.description: Scope at which local object needs to be created. Mandatory if object_type = LOCAL. Should not be provided for object_type = SHARED.

post_persona.name: persona
post_persona.description: Persona for which the local object needs to be created. Mandatory if object_type = LOCAL. Should not be provided for object_type = SHARED.

patch_object_type.name: object_type
patch_object_type.description: LOCAL - To update local objects. SHARED - To update shared objects. Default - Defaults to SHARED if not provided

patch_scope_id.name: scope_id
patch_scope_id.description: Scope at which local object needs to be updated. Mandatory if object_type = LOCAL. Should not be provided for object_type = SHARED.

patch_persona.name: persona
patch_persona.description: Persona for which the local object needs to be updated. Mandatory if object_type = LOCAL. Should not be provided for object_type = SHARED.

get_object_type.name: object_type
get_object_type.description: Retrieves LOCAL or SHARED or both(default) configuration objects.

get_scope_id.name: scope_id
get_scope_id.description: Configuration at a given scope. Mandatory for view_type = LOCAL.

get_persona.name: persona
get_persona.description: Filters configuration specific to given persona type. If not provided and view_type = LOCAL, then defaults to all persona.

effective.name: effective
effective.description: True - Returns effective configuration (i.e hierarchically merged configuration). False - Returns committed configuration at a given scope.

detailed.name: detailed
detailed.description: True - Includes annotations in the returned json to indicate the type of object, scope, and persona. False - Returns only config objects without annotations.

view_type.name: view_type
view_type.description: LIBRARY - Returns shared objects in library. For LIBRARY, all other parameters listed below, except 'detailed' , will be ignored. LOCAL - Returns configurations for a scope and one or more persona based on parameters below.

schema.description: The number of requests left for the time window.

X-RateLimit-Remaining.description: The number of requests left for the time window.

schema.description: The UTC date/time at which the current rate limit window resets.

X-RateLimit-Reset.description: The UTC date/time at which the current rate limit window resets.

ArubaWlan_WlanSsidsSchema.description:
A WLAN SSID (Service Set Identifier) is a unique identifier that names a wireless local area network (WLAN). It is essentially
the network name that is broadcast by a wireless access point (AP) to allow devices to identify and connect to the network. The SSID name can be up to 32
characters long and is case-sensitive. The SSID numbers can be up to 16 for per device. This feature is only applicable for AP.

mbssid-group-profile.description: Bind a MBSSID group to the SSID (Only affects 6GHz VAPs).

items.description:
Specify the zone names for the SSID profile.
When the zone is defined in SSID profile and if the same zone is defined on an AP,
the SSID is created on that AP.

ANY.description: Any of local or shared config object.

mbssid-group-profile.description: Bind a MBSSID group to the SSID (Only affects 6GHz VAPs).

items.description:
Specify the zone names for the SSID profile.
When the zone is defined in SSID profile and if the same zone is defined on an AP,
the SSID is created on that AP.

channel-utilization-threshold.description: DMO channel utilization parameter. Specifies threshold for multicast to unicast conversion

clients-threshold.description: Maximum clients threshold for DMO conversion.

local-proxy-ns.description: Respond to the IPv6 NDP on behalf of connected clients.

x-enumDescriptions.NAMED_VLAN: Configure the VLAN(s) using a named-VLAN
x-enumDescriptions.VLAN_RANGES: Configure the VLAN(s) as a list of VLAN ranges

vlan-selector.description:
Method to specify the VLAN(s) for this SSID:
If it is 'VLAN_RANGES', it can be a combination of
list of VLAN-ID-ranges and list of VLAN-IDs
Example: 61-65,67,69,71-75

vlan-name.description: Named-VLAN to map to this SSID

items.x-typeDescription:
VLANs or only single-tagged VLANs or both. A range is
specified as x-y where x and y are valid VLAN IDs
(1 <= vlan-id <= 4094). The range is assumed to be inclusive,
such that any VLAN-ID matching x <= VLAN-ID <= y falls within
the range.
items.description: List of VLANs or VLAN ranges to map to this SSID

out-of-service.description: Out of service type for this SSID

client-isolation.description:
Deny intra VLAN traffic.
Allowed traffic to be added into the global intra-vlan-traffic profile

max-ipv4-users.description:
Maximum number of wired IPv4 users
that can connect to the wireless client bridge.

content-filtering.description:
Content filtering configuration at WLAN SSID level.
This option control access to websites and applications based on their content, adding more security.

work-without-uplink.description: This option allows ssid to work without uplink.

ecwmin.description: Exponent of Contention Window Minimum (ECWMIN) parameter.

ecwmax.description: Exponent of Contention Window Maximum (ECWMAX) parameter.

ssid-utf8.description: Encodes the SSID. When enabled, the SSID name is displayed in the UTF-8 format.SSIDs are not encoded by default.

essid.description:
Name that uniquely identifies a wireless network.
The ESSID can be up to 32 characters.
If the ESSID includes spaces, you must enclose it in quotation marks.
This includes configuring use-alias, alias, name.

name.description: ESSID, The AP takes this parameter from its per-AP-ssid specific configuration.

advertise-location.description:
Enable broadcast of the AP Location Co-ordinate Information by unicast messages in FTM responder frames
and by broadcast messages in beacons frames and probe responses. Location Coordinate Information (LCI)
configuration in aruba-lci.yang is needed.

advertise-apname.description: Enable broadcast of AP Name information in the beacons frames and probe responses.

allowed-5ghz-radio.x-typeDescription: to control the 5GHz  upper/lowe band SSID creation.
allowed-5ghz-radio.description: 5GHz radio to which the SSID should be assigned.

cdc.description: Advertizes the Cellular Data Capability (CDC) attribute of an MBO.

disable-on-6ghz-mesh.description:
This is used when there are more than 3 6GHz SSIDs are created. It has to be set so that AP can know which SSID needs to be
disabled when mesh enabled. This might be no use later.

dot11k.description:
Enables 802.11k roaming on the SSID profile.The 802.11k protocol enables APs and clients to
dynamically measure the available radio resources.

dot11k-profile-name.description: To set the bound dot11k profile name

dot11r.description:
Enables 802.11r on the SSID profile.802.11r or fast BSS FT is an IEEE standard that permits continuous
connectivity across wireless devices during client mobility. Fast BSS Transition mechanism minimizes
the delay in roaming when a client transitions from one BSS to another within the same cluster.

x-enumDescriptions.WLAN_STATUS_FAILED_INVALID_PMKID: FT auth failure status code. AP shall reject the Authentication Request with status code 53 (i.e., Invalid PMKID) both ROKH UNREACHABLE and Invalid PMKID cases.
x-enumDescriptions.WLAN_STATUS_R0KH_UNREACHABLE: FT auth failure status code. AP shall respond to the Authentication Request with status code 28 (i.e., R0KH unreachable) for both ROKH UNREACHABLE and Invalid PMKID cases.
x-enumDescriptions.DYNAMIC:
FT auth failure dafault status code. If the RSNIE in the Authentication Request frame contains an invalid PMKR0Name and the AP has determined
that it is an invalid PMKR0Name, the AP shall reject the Authentication Request with status code 53 (i.e., Invalid PMKID). If the requested
R0KH is not reachable, the AP shall respond to the Authentication Request with status code 28 (i.e., R0KH unreachable).

auth-failure-code.description: When FT auth failure, AP send the corresponding reason code to client.

dot11r-ondemand-keyfetch.description:
Enables 802.11r on demand key fetch from cloud key management service when the AP's local key cache lookup fails for
client matching pairwise key to complete fast roaming.

dtim-period.description:
The DTIM interval determines how often the AP should deliver the buffered broadcast and multicast frames to associated clients in the powersaving mode.
When configured, the client checks for buffered data on the AP at the specified number of beacons.
You can also configure a higher value for DTIM interval for power saving.

ftm-responder.description: Enables the AP to send responses to Fine Time Measurement (FTM) queries sent from clients. This feature is supported on 500 Series and 600 Series access points.

hide-ssid.description: Enable hiding the SSID in beacons

short-preamble.description:
Enables short preamble for 802.11b/g radios. Network performance may be higher when short preamble is enabled.
In mixed radio environments, some 802.11b wireless client stations may experience difficulty associating with the AP using
short preamble. To use only long preamble, disable short preamble. Legacy client devices that use only long preamble generally
can be updated to support short preamble.

auth-req-thresh.description:
SNR threshold below which incoming authentication requests are ignored.
Use this parameter instead of the local probe request threshold parameter to filter out low SNR authentication request.

explicit-ageout-client.description: Allows APs to send a deauthentication frame to the client and clear client entry.

inactivity-timeout.description:
Configures a timeout value for the inactive client sessions.
When a client session is inactive for the specified duration, the session expires and the clients are required to log in again.

local-probe-req-thresh.description:
RSSI (Received Signal Strength Indicator) threshold value to limit the number of incoming probe requests.
When enabled, controls the system response to the broadcast probe requests
sent by clients to search for the available SSIDs and ignores the probe request if required.

max-clients-threshold.description:
Maximum number of wireless clients for the AP.
This parameter is limited to 1024 clients per radio. Default value for this parameter is the maximum number of clients supported by the AP.

max-retries.description: Maximum number of retries allowed for the AP to send a frame.

mbo.description: Enables the Agile Multiband Operations (MBO). Enables the mfp-capable, 802.11k and 802.11u-interworking implicitly on the AP.

mobility-domain-id.description:
Mobility Domain Identifier. An  AP uses this parameter to announce that it is a part of the AP group that
constitutes a mobility domain.

mfp-capable.description: When enabled, the SSID supports management frame protection (MFP) capable clients and traditional clients.

mfp-required.description: When enabled, the SSID only supports MFP capable clients.

qbss-load.description: Enables the AP to advertise the QBSS load element.

rf-band.description: Radio frequency band on which this SSID will be broadcast. You can select one of the following options:

x-enumDescriptions.RX_ONLY: Received data frames that are used for station refresh.
x-enumDescriptions.TX_ONLY: Transmitted data frames that are used for station refresh.

refresh-direction.x-typeDescription: The refresh direction of WLAN SSID profile.
refresh-direction.description: The refresh direction of WLAN SSID profile.

rrm-quiet-ie.description: Enable Radio Resource Management (RRM) IE profile to define the information elements advertised by an AP.

rts-threshold.description:
Wireless clients transmitting frames larger than this threshold must issue RTS and wait for the AP to respond with CTS.
This helps prevent mid-air collisions for wireless clients that are not within wireless peer range and cannot detect when other wireless clients are transmitting.

high-throughput.description:
High Throughput (HT): Introduced in 802.11n (Wi-Fi 4), includes features like wider channels (up to 40 MHz),
 MIMO (up to 4 spatial streams), 64-QAM, short guard interval, and frame aggregation to increase data rates and performance.
Very High Throughput (VHT): Introduced in 802.11ac (Wi-Fi 5), includes features like even wider channels (up to 160 MHz),
 higher modulation (256-QAM), more spatial streams (up to 8), MU-MIMO, and beamforming to further enhance data rates and network efficiency.
This configures high-throughput (HT) and very-high-throughput (VHT) related settings.
These features collectively enhance the data rates, capacity, and overall performance of wireless networks,
making them capable of handling large amounts of data efficiently.

ba-amsdu.description: Enables Receive AMSDU in Block ACK (BA) negotiation. If disabled, AP denies clients from sending AMSDU using BA agreement.

ldpc.description: If enabled, the AP will advertise LDPC support. LDPC improves data transmission over radio channels with high levels of background noise.

mpdu-agg.description: Enables MAC protocol data unit (MDPU) aggregation.

rx-ampdu-agg.description: Enables Receive AMPDU in Block ACK (BA) negotiation.

short-guard-intvl-20MHz.description: Enables use of short guard interval (400 ns) in 20 MHz mode.

short-guard-intvl-40MHz.description: Enables use of short guard interval (400 ns) in 40 MHz mode of operation.

short-guard-intvl-80MHz.description: Enables use of short guard interval (400 ns) in 80 MHz mode of operation.

stbc-rx-streams.description: Maximum number of spatial streams usable for STBC reception.

stbc-tx-streams.description: Maximum number of spatial streams usable for STBC transmission.

items.description:
A list of Modulation Coding Scheme (MCS) values or ranges of values to be supported on this SSID.
The MCS you choose determines the channel width (20 MHz vs. 40 MHz) and the number of spatial streams used by the mesh node.
To specify a series of different values, separate each value with a comma.

temporal-diversity.description:
Enable temporal diversity. When this setting is enabled and the client is not responding to 802.11 packets, the
AP will launch two hardware retries; if the hardware retries are not successful then it attempts software retries.

very-high-throughput.description: Enable support for VHT (802.11ac ) on the SSID.

vht-mu-txbf.description:
Enable VHT Multi-User Transmit Beamforming. If this parameter is disabled,
all other Multi-User Transmit Beamforming configuration parameters have no effect.

vht-supported-mcs-map.description:
Comma separated list of maximum supported MCS for spatial streams 1 through 4.
Valid values for maximum MCS are 7, 8, 9, and '-' (if spatial stream is not supported).
Maximum MCS of a spatial stream cannot be higher than the previous streams.
If an MCS is not valid for a particular combination of bandwidth and number of spatial streams,
it will not be used for Tx and Rx. Only '-' is not supported.

vht-txbf-explicit.description:
Enable VHT Explicit Transmit Beamforming for the 802.11ac-capable APs.
When this feature is enabled, the AP requests information about the MIMO channel and
uses that information to transmit data over multiple transmit streams using a calculated steering matrix.
The result is higher throughput due to improved signal at the beamformee (the receiving client).
If this parameter is disabled, all other transmit beamforming settings will not take effect.

g-legacy-rates.description:
Configures 802.11b/g rates related settings.
This includes configuring basic rates, beacon rate, transmit rates.

items.description:
Basic rates are the mandatory data rates that all devices must support to connect to the network.
These rates are used for essential network operations, such as management frames (beacons, probes) and control frames (ACKs, RTS/CTS).
Allows you to define a set of modulation rates to use for the clients.
Range: 1, 2, 5, 6, 9, 11, 12, 18, 24, 36, 48, 54 Mbps.

beacon-rate.description: Configures the beacon rate for 802.11g (use for DAS only). Using this parameter in normal operation may cause connectivity problems.

max-tx-rate.description: Configures the specify the maximum transmission rate.

min-tx-rate.description: Configures the specify the minimum transmission rate.

items.description:
Set of 802.11b/g rates at which the AP is allowed to send data. The actual transmit rate depends on what the client is able to handle,
based on information sent at the time of association and on the current error or loss rate of the client.

a-legacy-rates.description:
Configures 802.11a rates related settings.
This includes configuring basic rates, beacon rate, transmit rates.

items.description:
Basic rates are the mandatory data rates that all devices must support to connect to the network.
These rates are used for essential network operations, such as management frames (beacons, probes) and control frames (ACKs, RTS/CTS).
Allows you to define a set of modulation rates to use for the clients.
Range: 6, 9, 12, 18, 24, 36, 48, 54 Mbps.

beacon-rate.description: Beacon rate for 802.11a (use for DAS only). Using this parameter in normal operation may cause connectivity problems.

items.description:
Set of 802.11a rates at which the AP is allowed to send data. The actual transmit rate depends on what the client is able to handle,
based on information sent at the time of association and on the current error or loss rate of the client.

high-efficiency.description:
High Efficiency (HE) is the core feature set introduced in Wi-Fi 6 (802.11ax) to improve wireless network efficiency, capacity, and performance in dense environments.
This includes configuring MU-MIMO/OFDMA, MCS map, etc.

extremely-high-throughput.description:
Extremely High Throughput (EHT) is a feature set introduced in Wi-Fi 7 (802.11be) to enhance wireless performance,
particularly in high-density and high-throughput environments.
This includes configuring MLO, MCS map, beacon protection, etc.

mlo.description: Enable Multi-Link Operation (MLO) features on SSID.

supported-mcs-map.description:
Comma-separated list of max supported MCS for spatial streams 1
through 8. Valid values for max mcs are 7, 9, 11, 13 and
'-' ('-' means spatial stream is not supported, and
it's not supported at first spatial stream). Max mcs of
a spatial stream cannot be higher than the previous
stream's. If a MCS is not valid for a particular
combination of bandwidth and number of spatial streams,
it will not be used for Tx and Rx.

sae-sub-mode.description: Change Simultaneous Authentication of Equals (SAE) sub mode to legacy/gcm256-only/mix.

wmm-cfg.description:
Wi-Fi Multimedia (WMM) refers to a Wi-Fi Alliance interoperability certification,
based on the IEEE 802.11e standard. It provides basic QoS features to IEEE 802.11 networks.
WMM prioritizes traffic according to four Access Categories (ACs): voice (AC_VO), video (AC_VI), best effort (AC_BE), and background (AC_BK).
This includes configuring Enhanced Distributed Channel Access (EDCA) parameters for each AC of AP and Station (STA),
mapping between WMM ACs and Differentiated Services Codepoint (DSCP) tags.

ap-best-effort.description: Configures the EDCA parameters for AC_BE of AP.

ap-background.description: Configures the EDCA parameters for AC_BK of AP.

ap-video.description: Configures the EDCA parameters for AC_VI of AP.

ap-voice.description: Configures the EDCA parameters for AC_VO of AP.

sta-best-effort.description: Configures the EDCA parameters for AC_BE of STA.

sta-background.description: Configures the EDCA parameters for AC_BK of STA.

sta-video.description: Configures the EDCA parameters for AC_VI of STA.

sta-voice.description: Configures the EDCA parameters for AC_VO of STA.

enable.description:
Enables WiFi Multimedia (WMM), also known as IEEE 802.11e Enhanced Distribution Coordination Function.
WMM provides prioritization of specific traffic relative to other traffic in the network.

items.description: DSCP mapping for the background traffic.
DSCP mapping for the best-effort traffic.
DSCP mapping for the video traffic.
DSCP mapping for the voice traffic.

tspec.description: Allows APs to prioritize time-sensitive traffic such as voice traffic initiated by the client.

tspec-bandwidth.description: Reserves the configured bandwidth for prioritizing voice traffic when TSPEC is enabled.

qos-management.description:
Wi-Fi Quality of Service (QoS) Management certification delivers a standardized approach to QoS for devices and
applications to prioritize traffic flows for both client devices and APs.
This includes configuring QoS Management related configuration.

scs.description:
Enable/Disable Stream Classification Service (SCS) feature.
SCS: enables classification and Wi-Fi QoS treatment of specific IP flows, including flows to and from 5G core networks,
allowing sensitive traffic such as gaming, voice, and video to be prioritized over bulk data traffic

advertise-timing.description: Broadcast time advertisement and time zone IEs in beacon and probe response frames.

dot11v.description: Enable/Disable BSS Transition Management features defined by the 802.11v standard.

x-enumDescriptions.ALL_6GHZ: Allow a SSID to be up on all 6GHz radios.
x-enumDescriptions.FIRST_6GHZ: Allow a SSID to be up on first 6GHz radio.
x-enumDescriptions.SECOND_6GHZ: Allow a SSID to be up on second 6GHz radio.

allowed-6ghz-radio.x-typeDescription: Control the creation of SSIDs on the first, second, or all 6GHz radios.
allowed-6ghz-radio.description: Control the creation of SSIDs on the first, second, or all 6GHz radios.

advertise-location-identifier.description:
Configuration for a public location identifier. The location identifier is from IEEE Standard 802.11,
it includes an indirect Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) or FQND to the location information for the
location subject.

enable.description:
Enable broadcasting two kinds (HELD and SUPL) of links to client in Access Network Query Protocol (ANQP)
element 267. HELD means Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) enabled location delivery (HELD) and SUPL means
Secure User Plane Location.

http-enabled-location-delivery.description:
A public identifier, like Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) or Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN), will supply AP
location information.

supl-server.description:
SUPL means Secure User Plane Location, one Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) or Fully Qualified
Domain Name (FQDN) should be configured to supply AP location information.

advertise-location-civic.description:
In IEEE Standard 802.11, enable sending programmed civic information in Access Network Query Protocol (ANQP)
and neighbor report responses.

ArubaRadio_HighEfficiencyGroup.description: a group of high effenciency related parameters, might be used both in rf profile and ssid profile.

duration-based-rts.description:
Indicates HE duration-based RTS value.
When the TXOP is greater than the configured HE duration based RTS value, RTS/CTS exchange should be used.
Range: 0-1023(units: 32ms). Default 1023. 1023: HE duration-based RTS will be disabled.

mu-ofdma.description: Enable downlink HE MU-OFDMA(Multi-User Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiple Access).

ul-mu-mimo.description: Enable uplink HE MU-OFDMA(Multi-User Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiple Access).

supported-mcs-map.description:
Comma-separated list of max supported MCS for spatial streams 1
through 8. Valid values for max mcs are 7, 9, 11 and
'-' ('-' means spatial stream is not supported, and
it's not supported at first spatial stream). Max mcs of
a spatial stream cannot be higher than the previous
stream's. If a MCS is not valid for a particular
combination of bandwidth and number of spatial streams,
it will not be used for Tx and Rx.

dynamic-fragmentation-level.x-typeDescription:
Dynamic fragmentation level is supported by AP.(only
configurable in bridge/d-tunnel mode) Range: 0-3.
Default 0. level-0: not support dynamic fragmentation.
level-1: for support for dynamic fragments that are
contained within a S-MPDU, no support for dynamic
fragments within an A-MPDU that is not a S-MPDU.
level-2: for support for dynamic fragments that are
contained within a S-MPDU and support for up to one
dynamic fragment for each MSDU within an A-MPDU.
level-3: for support for dynamic fragments that are
contained within a S-MPDU and support for up to four
dynamic fragment for each MSDU within an A-MPDU. Note:
Further limited by each AP's radio HW capabilities
dynamic-fragmentation-level.description:
Dynamic fragmentation level is supported by AP.(only
configurable in bridge/d-tunnel mode) Range: 0-3.
Default 0. level-0: not support dynamic fragmentation.
level-1: for support for dynamic fragments that are
contained within a S-MPDU, no support for dynamic
fragments within an A-MPDU that is not a S-MPDU.
level-2: for support for dynamic fragments that are
contained within a S-MPDU and support for up to one
dynamic fragment for each MSDU within an A-MPDU.
level-3: for support for dynamic fragments that are
contained within a S-MPDU and support for up to four
dynamic fragment for each MSDU within an A-MPDU. Note:
Further limited by each AP's radio HW capabilities

dot1x-timer-idrequest-period.description: Time period (in seconds) to wait for a response from a client before retransmitting an EAPoL PDU.

l2-auth-failthrough.description: Continue with 802.1x authentication even if MAC auth fail.

x-enumDescriptions.WPA2_PERSONAL: WPA-2 with AES encryption using a preshared key.
x-enumDescriptions.WPA2_ENTERPRISE: WPA-2 with AES encryption and dynamic keys using 802.1X.
x-enumDescriptions.ENHANCED_OPEN: Improved data encryption in open Wi-Fi networks and protects data from sniffing. Enhanced open replaces open system as the default opmode.
x-enumDescriptions.WPA3_SAE: WPA3 with AES encryption using Simultaneous Authentication of Equals.
x-enumDescriptions.WPA3_ENTERPRISE_CCM_128: WPA3 with AES CCM-128 encryption and dynamic keys using 802.1X.
x-enumDescriptions.WPA3_ENTERPRISE_CNSA: WPA3 with AES GCM-256 encryption using CNSA (192 bit).
x-enumDescriptions.WPA_ENTERPRISE: WPA with TKIP encryption and dynamic keys using 802.1X.
x-enumDescriptions.WPA_PERSONAL: WPA with TKIP and WPA with AES encryption using a PSK.
x-enumDescriptions.WPA2_MPSK_LOCAL: Multiple Pre-Shared Keys(MPSK) local using the local database to do authentication.
x-enumDescriptions.DPP:
Device Provisioning Protocol. It is a Wi-Fi Alliance protocol designed to simplify the process of
securely provisioning and onboarding devices onto a network without needing a pre-shared key (PSK).
x-enumDescriptions.WPA2_PSK_AES_DPP: WPA-2 with AES and DPP encryption using a psk.
x-enumDescriptions.WPA2_AES_DPP: WPA-2 with AES and dpp encryption using 802.1x.
x-enumDescriptions.WPA3_SAE_DPP: WPA3 with AES and DPP encryption using Simultaneous Authentication of Equals.
x-enumDescriptions.WPA3_AES_CCM_128_DPP: WPA3 with AES CCM-128 and DPP encryption and dynamic keys using 802.1X.
x-enumDescriptions.WPA3_AES_GCM_256_DPP: WPA3 with AES GCM-256 and DPP encryption.
x-enumDescriptions.BOTH_WPA_WPA2_PSK: WPA with TKIP and WPA with AES and WPA-2 with TKIP and WPA-2 with AES encryption using a PSK.
x-enumDescriptions.BOTH_WPA_WPA2_DOT1X: WPA with TKIP and WPA with AES and WPA-2 with TKIP and WPA-2 with AES encryption using 802.1x.

ArubaWlanSecurity_SecurityCommonConfig.description: Wireless and wired common parameters for security.

radius-reauth-interval.description: Radius reauth interval, when session timeout, device do reauth.

use-ip-for-calling-station-id.description: Use IP as Calling Station Id.

radius-loc-obj-in-access.description: Enable location in radius access request.

radius-loc-obj-in-accting.description: Enable location in radius accounting request.

download-role.description: A user is assigned a role by ClearPass Policy Manager. If the role is not defined on the Instant AP, the role attributes can also be downloaded automatically.

ArubaWlanSecurity_AuthServerConfig.description: Group for Radius accounting related configurations.

primary-auth-server.description: Primary server for authentication under SSID profile or wired port profile.

backup-auth-server.description: Backup server for authentication under SSID profile or wired port profile.

auth-server-group.description: Server group to be used for authentication under the SSID profile or wired port profile.

ArubaWlanSecurity_RadiusAccountingConfig.description: Group for Radius accounting related configurations.

primary-acct-server.description: Primary accounting servers for radius accounting under the SSID profile or wired port profile.

backup-acct-server.description: Backup accounting servers for radius accounting under the SSID profile or wired port profile.

acct-server-group.description:
Server group to be used for accounting under the SSID profile or wired port profile. The primary/backup accounting
server and accounting server group only support one configuration at a time. If both are configured simultaneously,
the accounting server group will be used during accounting.

x-enumDescriptions.USER_ASSOCIATION: When configured, the accounting starts when the client associates to the network successfully and stops when the client is disconnected.
x-enumDescriptions.USER_AUTHENTICATION: when configured, the accounting starts only after client authentication is successful and stops when the client logs out of the network.

cp-accounting-mode.x-typeDescription: Configure an accounting mode for the captive portal users.
cp-accounting-mode.description: Radius Accounting Mode just for captive portal.

pre-auth-role.description: Configure a pre-authentication role to allow some access to the guest users before the client authentication.

mac-auth-only-role.description:
Allow administrator to create a MAC Authentication only role for role-based access rule when MAC authentication is enabled for Captive Portal.
If MAC authentication is successful, the mac-auth-only role will be assigned to the client.

machine-auth.description:
Configure a machine authentication rule. When a Windows device boots, it logs onto the network domain using a machine account. Within the domain, the device is authenticated
before computer group policies and software settings can be executed; this process is known as machine authentication. Machine authentication ensures that only authorized devices
are allowed on the network. You can configure 802.1X for both user and machine authentication. This tightens the authentication process further, since both the device and user need
to be authenticated. This feature is applicable for 802.1x authenticaion and it is only applicable for AP.

machine-only-role.description: Client can obtain machine auth role, when it only pass machine authentication. Assign different rights to clients based on whether their hardware device supports machine authentication.

user-only-role.description: Client can obtain user only role, when using username and password pass authentication.

default-role.description: When Default role is configured, default role is used. If default role isn't configured, use the role that the role name is same as SSID profile name.

pmk-cache-delete-on-leave.description: Delete key cache entry when user entry is deleted.

wpa-key-period.description: Set the time period between each WPA/WPA2/WPA3 key exchange.

wpa-key-retries.description: Set the Number of times WPA/WPA2/WPA3 Key Messages are retried.

captive-portal-landing-page-delay.description: The delay time of landing redirect-url page after captive-portal authentication is successful.

captive-portal-proxy-server.description: Configure a Captive Portal proxy server to match your browser configuration by specifying the IP address and port number.

oneOf.x-typeDescription:
An IPv4 address in dotted quad notation using the default
zone.

An IPv6 address represented as either a full address; shortened
or mixed-shortened formats, using the default zone.

ip.description: Specify a IP for Captive Portal proxy.

port.description: Specify a port for Captive Portal proxy.

passpoint.description:
Passpoint is a WFA specification based upon the 802.11u protocol that provides wireless clients
with a streamlined mechanism to discover and authenticate to suitable networks, and allows
mobile users the ability to roam between partner networks without additional authentication.

mac-authentication-delimiter.description: The MAC address format to be used in the RADIUS request messages for authentication.

mac-authentication-upper-case.description: The case for MAC address format to be used in the RADIUS request messages for authentication.

max-authentication-failures.description: Number of consecutive authentication failures, before Station is denylisted.

priority-use-local-cache.description: Local cache exist, local cache priority.

enforce-dhcp.description: Require IP address to be obtained using DHCP.

x-enumDescriptions.CENTRAL_NAC: Using Central Network Access Control(NAC) as the Captive Portal Server.

captive-portal-type.description: For Captive Portal Server, AP supports Central Network Access Control(NAC) and External Captive Portal.

captive-portal.description: Associate one Captive Portal profile under SSID profile or wired port profile.

items.description: For Captive Portal Server, customer can disable redirection to the captive portal based on the type of current uplink.

personal-security.description:
WLAN Personal Security refers to a wireless network security mode designed for home and small office environments,
where network access is secured using a pre-shared key (PSK) instead of complex authentication methods like those used in enterprise networks.
WLAN Personal Security is using WPA, WPA2-Personal or WPA3-Personal. This feature is only applicable for AP.

x-enumDescriptions.STRING: The length of string passphrase supports 8-63.
x-enumDescriptions.HEX: The length of hexadecimal passphrase supports 64.

passphrase-format.description: For passphrase, AP supports hexadecimal and string.

wpa-passphrase.x-typeDescription:
A custom derived type for special use cases. This type takes a plaintext password and uses
Vault's 3rd party API to encrypt the password. The intended use case is to encrypt and store
customer credentials which will be used later to login to 3rd party services.
wpa-passphrase.description: Defines a WPA passphrase with which you can generate a PSK. WPA passphrase for Character passphrase, supports 8-63. Hex passphrase only supports 64

x-enumDescriptions.128BIT: The key length of WEP static.
x-enumDescriptions.64BIT: The key length of WEP static.

wep-key-size.description: WEP-static key size. It can be 128bit or 64bit.

wep-key.x-typeDescription:
A custom derived type for special use cases. This type takes a plaintext password and uses
Vault's 3rd party API to encrypt the password. The intended use case is to encrypt and store
customer credentials which will be used later to login to 3rd party services.
wep-key.description: Static WEP key associated with the key index. The WEP key values can be 10 or 26 hexadecimal characters in length.

called-station-id.description:
Configure this parameter to be sent with the RADIUS attribute Called Station ID for authentication and accounting requests. For AP, this API is applicable for
WLAN profile and AP port profile. For GW, this API is applicable for the authentication server profile. This feature is applicable for AP and GW.

type.description:
Configure the called-station-id types.
For AP, The type includes AP group, AP MAC address, AP name, AP IP or user vlan. The default value is AP MAC address.

mac-address-delimiter.description: By default, called-station-id is AP MAC Address string and no delimiter, when configure mac-address-delimiter, AP MAC Address will be added delimiter in authentication packet.

upper-case.description: By default, called-station-id is AP MAC Address string, when enabled upper-case, AP MAC Address will be changed to upper case in authentication packet.

include-ssid-delimiter.description: The delimiter between mac address and SSID. For example, the delimiter is dash. The called-station-id like aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff-wlanssid.

assignment-rules.description:
Assign the client a user role, VLAN ID or VLAN name based on attributes. For GW and AP, the attributes is returned for the client by the authentication server and this API is applicable for
auth server group. For AP, this API is also applicable WLAN profile and if this API works in WLAN profile, the attributes can be returned for the client by the authentication server or other
attributes such as mac-address, dhcp-option, AP-Name, etc. Rules are ordered: the first rule that matches the configured condition is applied. VLAN IDs and VLAN names cannot be listed together.
This feature is only applicable for AP and GW.

sequence-id.description: The sequence id determines the rule order.

attribute.description:
Attribute returned by the authentication server.
For AP, it also includes some custom attributes like mac-address, dhcp-option and fw_mode.

operand.description:
Match operand, For GW, the VSA value. For AP, it is VSA value under server group profile.
It is VSA value and mac-addrees, dhcp-option and fw_mode under SSID profile and AP wired port profile.

vlan.description: This is the assigned VLAN when there is a rule match.

role.description: This is the assigned Role when there is a rule match.

Successful200.description: Success response returned from the server.

Error400.description: Error details returned from the server.

message.example: Bad request. Invalid values supplied in request.

Error401.description: Error details returned from the server.

Error403.description: Error details returned from the server.

Error404.description: Error details returned from the server.

message.example: Not found. Yang / Corresponding Rule is missing.

Error406.description: Error details returned from the server.

Error408.description: Error details returned from the server.

Error412.description: Error details returned from the server.

Error429.description: Error details returned from the server.

Error500.description: Error details returned from the server.
